questions.text: What could be the potential diagnosis for a 34-year-old male who has been consuming maize as his main diet for an extended period and is now experiencing symptoms such as abdominal pain, decreased appetite, and diarrhea? Additionally, upon examination, glossitis (inflammation of the tongue) and a pigmented rash in sun-exposed areas were observed, along with a lesion on his neck.
Which of the subsequent stages in the vitamin D metabolism necessitates exposure to sunlight?
Which of the following substance, facilitate the absorption of dietary iron?
A young boy presented with fissured tongue, lips, and lesions in the angle of the mouth.On investigation, he had low RBC glutathione reductase activity. Which vitamin is deficient here?

What is the underlying cause of the presenting symptoms in a 21-year-old individual with chronic alcoholism who is admitted to the emergency department with confusion, tremors, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia?
questions.explanation:
WERNICKE-KORSAKOFF SYNDROME (CEREBRAL BERI-BERI)

Clinical Manifestations

Wernicke Encephalopathy:

Symptoms: Ophthalmoplegia, nystagmus, cerebellar ataxia, global confusion.

Korsakoff Psychosis:

Symptoms: Anterograde and retrograde amnesia, sensory agnosia, and confabulation.

Causes of Thiamine Deficiency in Alcoholics
  • Increased thiamine requirements due to alcohol consumption. Alcohol is a source of empty calories.
  • Inhibition of intestinal thiamine absorption by alcohol.

Metabolic Implications
  • Impaired conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA.
  • Accumulation of pyruvate and lactate in the blood.
  • Potential for life-threatening lactic acidosis.

Progression and Risk Factors
  • Progression from Wernicke encephalopathy to Korsakoff psychosis if untreated.
  • Associated with severely compromised nutritional status, often due to chronic alcoholism.

MRI findings

Symmetrical T2/FLAIR signal increase in the mammillary bodies, dorsomedial thalami, tectal plate, periaqueductal area, and around the third ventricle.

questions.text: Which antioxidant deficiency can cause the symptoms of iron-deficiency anemia, painful and tender joints, and bleeding manifestations in a 34-year-old woman who primarily consumes packaged and reheated meals?
To evaluate a deficiency of vitamin B2 (riboflavin), one can assess the activity of:

questions.explanation:
XN

X1

  • X1B: Bitot spots.

X2
  • Corneal xerosis.

X3
  • X3A: Corneal ulceration, less than one-third.
  • X3B: Corneal ulceration, more than one-third.

XS
  • Corneal scar.

XF
  • Xerophthalmic fundus.

questions.text: A farmer presented with loose stools and rashes over the sun-exposed areas. Careful diet history reveals a diet rich in maize. Which of the following deficiencies would you suspect?
A patient presents with gum bleeding, petechiae, poor wound healing, and other related symptoms. Which of the following vitamin deficiencies is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Vitamin C Deficiency (Scurvy)

Cause

Poor dietary intake (malnutrition, alcoholism, elderly, infants on cow's milk)

Key Symptoms

Bleeding gums, petechiae, bruising, corkscrew hairs, poor wound healing

Other Signs

Subperiosteal hemorrhage, joint pain, anemia, weakness

Diagnosis

Clinical features, low plasma vitamin C levels

Treatment

Vitamin C supplementation

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment for a 45-year-old male patient with a history of chronic alcoholism, who is currently experiencing symptoms of confusion, ataxia, and diplopia?

options.label: A
options.text: Vitamin B1 injection followed by glucose infusion

questions.correct_answer: A. Vitamin B1 injection followed by glucose infusion
questions.explanation:
WERNICKE-KORSAKOFF SYNDROME (CEREBRAL BERI-BERI)

Clinical Manifestations

Wernicke Encephalopathy:

Symptoms: Ophthalmoplegia, nystagmus, cerebellar ataxia, global confusion.

Korsakoff Psychosis:

Symptoms: Anterograde and retrograde amnesia, sensory agnosia, and confabulation. (Option B)

Causes of Thiamine Deficiency in Alcoholics
  • Increased thiamine requirements due to alcohol consumption. Alcohol is a source of empty calories.
  • Inhibition of intestinal thiamine absorption by alcohol.

Metabolic Implications
  • Impaired conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA.
  • Accumulation of pyruvate and lactate in the blood.
  • Potential for life-threatening lactic acidosis.

Progression and Risk Factors
  • Progression from Wernicke encephalopathy to Korsakoff psychosis if untreated.
  • Associated with severely compromised nutritional status, often due to chronic alcoholism.

MRI findings

Symmetrical T2/FLAIR signal increase in the mammillary bodies, dorsomedial thalami, tectal plate, periaqueductal area, and around the third ventricle.

Treatment

Acute Phase (Wernicke Encephalopathy):

  • Intravenous thiamine (100 mg) for 3-7 days is standard; however, higher doses (500 mg TID) may be required if symptoms persist.
  • Glucose should be administered after thiamine to prevent exacerbating symptoms.

Chronic Phase (Korsakoff’s Psychosis):

  • Continue oral thiamine indefinitely, especially in alcohol-dependent patients.
  • Address co-occurring deficiencies, provide nutritional support, and consider rehabilitation or residential care if needed.

A child presents with thinning of hair and scaling of the scalp. On taking further history, it is found that she consumes raw eggs in her diet regularly. The given manifestations are due to the deficiency of which of the following vitamins?

A baby presents with the clinical features shown in the image, including characteristic perioral and perianal rash along with a history of diarrhea. Which of the following is the most likely deficiency responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Zinc Deficiency

Cause

Congenital (SLC39A4 mutation) or acquired (malnutrition, chronic diarrhea)

Key Skin Features

Perioral, perianal, and acral dermatitis with erythematous, scaly plaques

Other Symptoms

Growth retardation, diarrhea, alopecia, immune dysfunction

Diagnosis

Low serum zinc levels

Treatment

Zinc supplementation

questions.text: Which deficiency is most likely in a patient with delayed wound healing and alopecia?
questions.explanation:
Zinc

Function
  • Component of metalloenzymes
  • Involved in protein, DNA, and RNA synthesis
  • Necessary for steroid hormone receptors
  • Essential for spermatogenesis and fetal growth

Clinical Features of Zinc Deficiency
  • Diarrhea
  • Alopecia
  • Muscle wasting
  • Depression
  • Irritability
  • Rash
  • Delayed wound healing
  • Scaly dermatitis

Diagnostic Level of Zinc Deficiency

Serum zinc level <12 μmol/L (70 μg/dL)

questions.text: A child presents with deformities, normal serum calcium, normal PTH, low phosphate, and elevated ALP. Which is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: B
options.text: Vitamin D Dependent Rickets Type 1 (VDDR type 1)

options.label: C
options.text: Vitamin D Dependent Rickets Type 2 (VDDR type 2)

questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Hypophosphatemic rick

Calcipenic rickets/Nutritional rickets  Phosphoenic rickets/renal rickets
  • Cause: Deficiency of calcium due to defective absorption absorption and improper supply of calcium.
  • Low calcium levels are present.
  •  It is due to low phosphate levels.
  • It is caused by excessive excretion in the kidney.

questions.text: Which of the following are metabolites of methanol poisoning?
Which vitamin acts as a coenzyme required for Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase (G6PD)?
questions.explanation:
Niacin (Vitamin B3)

Chemical Structure
  • Niacin: Pyridine-3-carboxylic acid.
  • Niacinamide: Acid amide derivative.
  • Active tissue form: Niacinamide

Coenzyme Forms and Functions
  • NAD+: Generates 2.5 ATPs in oxidative phosphorylation.
  • NADPH: Used in reductive biosynthesis (e.g., fatty acid synthesis).
  • Provides ADP-ribose for protein modification (ADP-ribosylation).

Synthesis and Metabolism
  • 60 mg of tryptophan = 1 mg niacin (requires pyridoxal phosphate-dependent kynureninase).
  • Niacin attaches to ribose phosphate, forming a mononucleotide, then combines with AMP to form dinucleotides.

Deficiency Causes
  • Dietary Deficiency: Staple diets like maize (bound niacin) or sorghum (leucine inhibits niacin conversion).
  • Enzyme Defects: Pyridoxal deficiency inhibits kynureninase activity.
  • Drugs: Isoniazid inhibits pyridoxal phosphate formation.
  • Congenital Disorders: Hartnup disease (impaired tryptophan absorption and increased urinary excretion).
  • Carcinoid Syndrome: Excess tryptophan used for serotonin synthesis.

Clinical Condition
  • Pellagra: Niacin or tryptophan deficiency causing "rough skin".
  • Symptoms (3 Ds): Dermatitis (Casal’s necklace), Diarrhea (may involve blood/mucus), Dementia (irritability, poor memory, delirium).

Sources
  • Richest: Dried yeast, rice
  • , liver, peanuts, cereals, legumes, meat, fish.
  • 50% requirement met by tryptophan conversion.

RDA
  • Adults: 20 mg/day; Additional 5 mg during lactation.

Therapeutic Uses
  • Lowers serum cholesterol and Lp(a) by reducing free fatty acid flux from adipose tissue.

Toxicity
  • Excess (>50 mg/day): Vasodilation, itching, liver damage.

questions.explanation: Correct Option D - 3, 4

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding folate deficiency?

options.label: A
options.text: Folate supplementation in pregnancy prevents NTD

options.label: B
options.text: High Homocysteine and Normal Methylmalonic acid

options.label: D
options.text: Treat coexisting B12 deficiency before initiating folate therapy

questions.correct_answer: C. Hemolytic anemia is a feature
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Hemolytic anemia is a featu

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presents with agitation, confusion, and gait abnormalities. What vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Features of Chronic Alcoholism

Vit. B12 Deficiency

(Option C)
  • Chronic alcohol use can lead to functional vitamin B12 deficiency, even if blood tests show normal levels.
  • Alcohol interferes with vitamin B12 absorption and metabolism.
  • Vitamin B12 is essential for DNA synthesis and maintaining healthy nerves and red blood cells.
  • Symptoms of B12 deficiency include fatigue, weakness, numbness, and balance problems.
  • Alcohol can damage the liver, which might cause falsely high B12 levels in blood tests, making diagnosis challenging.

Folate Deficiency

(Option B ruled out)
  • Folate (vitamin B9) deficiency is common in chronic alcoholics, affecting 6-80% of them.
  • Alcohol disrupts folate by impairing its absorption, transport, and liver storage.
  • Poor diet in alcoholics worsens folate deficiency.
  • Folate is crucial for making red blood cells and DNA.
  • Deficiency can cause megaloblastic anaemia and neurological issues like peripheral neuropathy and cognitive problems.

Hypoglycemia

 
  • Chronic alcohol consumption can cause low blood sugar (hypoglycemia), especially if not eating enough.
  • Alcohol produces a high NADH/NAD+ ratio in the cytoplasm, the high NADH level favours the conversion of pyruvate to lactate, leading to lactic acidosis.
  • Deficiency of pyruvate leads to inadequate formationof oxaloacetate which blocks gluconeogenesis
  • This results in low blood sugar levels.
  • Symptoms of alcohol-induced hypoglycemia include confusion, irritability, and, in severe cases, loss of consciousness.

questions.text: What are the consequences of a deficiency in Vitamin A?
questions.explanation:
XN
  • Night blindness.

X1
  • X1A: Conjunctival xerosis.
  • X1B: Bitot spots.

X2
  • Corneal xerosis.

X3
  • X3A: Corneal ulceration, less than one-third.
  • X3B: Corneal ulceration, more than one-third.

XS
  • Corneal scar.

XF
  • Xerophthalmic fundus.

questions.text: A patient presenting with bleeding gums and easy bruisability was diagnosed with scurvy. This is due to
A child was brought with pedal edema and cheilosis.Cardiomegaly was present. What is the vitamin deficiency associated with this clinical presentation?
questions.explanation:
Conditions

Biochemical Role of Thiamine

Deficiency Manifestations

Dry Beriberi

 

Essential for carbohydrate metabolism and nerve function

CNS manifestations such as peripheral neuritis, sensory disturbances, difficulty walking, and paralysis due to CNS manifestations.

Wet Beriberi

Thiamine is necessary for the PDH complex and low activity causes Lactic acidosis. Lactic acidosis causes vasodilatation and hence cardiovascular manifestations.

Cardiovascular manifestations such as oedema, palpitations, breathlessness, and heart failure.

Maple Syrup Urine Disease

 

Cofactor for decarboxylation of branched-chain keto acids

Accumulation of branched-chain keto acids leads to convulsions, severe mental retardation, vomiting, acidosis, coma, and death.

Lactic Acidosis

 

Cofactor for pyruvate dehydrogenase, converting pyruvate to acetyl-CoA

Impaired conversion leads to increased lactate and pyruvate levels, causing lactic acidosis.

questions.text: A family consumes only polished rice. Which of the following combinations of vitamin deficiency and enzymatic defect will be present in this family?

VITAMINS

XI

Plasma thromboplastin antecedent (PTA)

XII

Hageman factor

XIII

Fibrin stabilizing factor

questions.text: The image illustrates which vitamin deficiency?
questions.explanation:
Niacin (Vitamin B3)
Chemical Structure
  • Niacin: Pyridine-3-carboxylic acid.
  • Niacinamide: Acid amide derivative.
  • Active tissue form: Niacinamide
Coenzyme Forms and Functions
  • NAD+: Generates 2.5 ATPs in oxidative phosphorylation.
  • NADPH: Used in reductive biosynthesis (e.g., fatty acid synthesis).

  • Enzyme Defects: Pyridoxal deficiency inhibits kynureninase activity.
  • Drugs: Isoniazid inhibits pyridoxal phosphate formation.

questions.text: Which of the following shows functional assessment of B1 deficiency?
questions.explanation:
B-Complex Vitamin

Deficiency Disease

Diagnostic Test

Vitamin B1 (Thiamine)

Beriberi (wet and dry types)

Blood thiamine level, transketolase activity test

Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin)

Ariboflavinosis

Blood riboflavin level

Vitamin B3 (Niacin)

Pellagra

Urinary excretion of N-methylnicotinamide, tryptophan load test

Vitamin B5 (Pantothenic Acid)

Pantothenic Acid Deficiency

Dietary assessment, symptoms evaluation

Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine)

Pyridoxine Deficiency

Blood pyridoxal phosphate level

Vitamin B7 (Biotin)

Biotin Deficiency

Urinary excretion of 3-hydroxyisovaleric acid

Vitamin B9 (Folate)

Folate Deficiency

Blood folate level, red blood cell folate level

Vitamin B12 (Cobalamin)

Vitamin B12 Deficiency

Serum vitamin B12 level, methylmalonic acid level, homocysteine level

questions.text: Which mineral in excess causes alkali disease in livestock?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A

Mineral

Toxicity Symptoms

Iron

Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, organ damage

Copper

Abdominal pain, jaundice, liver and kidney damage

Zinc

Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, stomach cramps

Selenium

Hair loss, brittle hooves, sloughing of hooves

Manganese

Nervous system disorders, tremors, muscle spasms

Fluoride

Dental fluorosis, skeletal fluorosis

Lead

Anemia, neurological damage, developmental issues

Cadmium

Kidney damage, lung damage, carcinogenic effects

Mercury

Neurological damage, cognitive impairments

Aluminum

Neurological disorders, bone disorders

Arsenic

Skin lesions, cancer, cardiovascular and respiratory issues
